questions.question: Salivary amylase is activated by which of the following ions?
questions.explanation: Salivary amylase is activated by Cl-.Human salivary and pancreatic amylases are activated by chloride (Cl-). They have optimumactivities near-neutral pH (7.4). They hydrolyze internal 1:4° linkages but spare 1:6° linkages andterminal 1:4° linkages in starch.

questions.question: Where does the digestion of disaccharides occur?
questions.explanation: Digestion of disaccharides occurs in the small intestine. The enzymes maltase, sucrase, isomaltase, lactase, and trehalase are located in the enterocytes covering the intestinal microvilli brush border. The disaccharides are digested into their constituent monosaccharides as they come into contact with these enterocytes.

questions.question: The mechanism by which glucose is absorbed in the intestine is:
questions.explanation: Glucose is absorbed in the intestine by secondary active transport.On the basolateral side, there is active transport of sodium ions out of the cell into the interstitialfluid. This depletes sodium inside the cell. Because of this Na+ concentration difference, moreNa+ binds to the SGLT on the luminal side. This increases the affinity of SGLT for glucose andglucose binds to it.Then, both the Na+ and glucose are transported together to the interior of the cell. Thus, glucoseis absorbed in the intestine by secondary active transport. The energy for glucose transport isprovided indirectly, by the active transport of Na+ out of the cell. The glucose moves out of thecell into the blood across the basolateral membrane by facilitated diffusion mediated via GLUT.586Na+SGLT 1Glucose/GalactoseGlucose absorptionNa+-K+ATPaseNa+Glucose8K+ATPFructoseGLUT 5FructoseGLUT2LumenNaEnterocyteBlood(Basolateral)OMARROWK+

questions.question: Which of the following is a true statement?

options.A: Fructose is absorbed in the intestine by secondary active transport
options.B: SGLT2 is involved in absorption of monosaccharide in intestine
options.C: GLUT2 is involved in transport of glucose from enterocyte into interstitium577
options.D: GLUT4 is responsible for basal glucose uptake in many organs

questions.explanation: GLUT2 is involved in the transport of glucose from the enterocyte into the interstitium (or out ofthe enterocytes).The image below shows the function of GLUT 2 on enterocytes.Glucose absorption+NaNa+Na+-K ATPaseNa+Glucose/GalactoseSGLT 1k+8K+GlucoseFructoseRATPGLUT 5GLUTFructose2LumenEnterocyteBlood(Basolateral)OMARROWOption A: Fructose absorption is through facilitated diffusion from the intestinal lumen into theenterocyte by GLUT5 and out of the enterocytes into the interstitium by GLUT2.Option B: SGLT1 is involved in the absorption of glucose into the enterocyte. SGLT2 is responsiblefor glucose transport out of the renal tubules.Option D: GLUT1 is responsible for basal glucose uptake in many organs.587

questions.question: Which of the following is the main enzyme involved in the hydrolysis of 1,6° linkage of starch?
questions.explanation: The main enzyme involved in the hydrolysis of 1,6° linkage of starch is isomaltase. Both salivary and the pancreatic α-amylases hydrolyze internal 1:4° linkages but spare 1:6° linkages and terminal 1:4° linkages of starch.

questions.question: What is chymotrypsinogen?
questions.explanation: Chymotrypsinogen is a zymogen. Zymogens (proenzymes) are inactive precursors of the enzymes. Most of the peptidases (proteases) are present in the form of proenzymes. Trypsinogen, chymotrypsinogen, proelastase, procarboxypeptidase A, and procarboxypeptidase B are zymogens. Activation of proteases: Trypsinogen, Chymotrypsinogen, Proelastase, Procarboxypeptidase A, Procarboxypeptidase B. Trypsinogen is activated by Enterokinase to Trypsin, which then activates other zymogens to their active forms: Trypsin to Chymotrypsin, Elastase, Carboxypeptidase A, and Carboxypeptidase B.

questions.question: Which of the following processes converts trypsinogen to trypsin?

options.C: Removal of a few amino acids

questions.explanation: Trypsinogen is converted to trypsin by the removal of a few amino acids.All proenzymes are converted to their active form by selective proteolysis (removal of a few aminoacids).Enterokinase cleaves trypsinogen to yield active trypsin. It is located on the brush border ofduodenal enterocytes.588TrypsinogenEnterokinaseTrypsin

questions.question: Which of the following protects the normal pancreas from autodigestion?
questions.explanation: The synthesis and secretion of proteases as catalytically inactive proenzymes protect the normalpancreas from autodigestion.All the protease proenzymes present in the pancreatic juice get converted to their active form onlyin the small intestinal lumen (site of action).If proenzymes get activated in the pancreas (site of origin), they can digest the entire pancreaswithin a few hours, giving rise to the condition called acute pancreatitis.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an endopeptidase?
questions.explanation: Carboxypeptidase is an exopeptidase, not endopeptidase.Peptidases (proteases) are of two types:•Endopeptidases - they act at interior peptide bonds in the peptide molecules. Ex- pepsin, trypsin,chymotrypsin, elastase.Exopeptidases - they hydrolyze the amino acids at the carboxyl ends of the polypeptides, one at atime. Ex- carboxypeptidase, aminopeptidase.

questions.question: Peptide transporter 1 is involved in the absorption of which of the following?
questions.explanation: Peptide transporter 1 (PepT1) is involved in the absorption of the dipeptide.The dipeptides and tripeptides are transported along with H+ into enterocytes by a system knownas peptide transporter 1 (PepT1).589These peptides undergo intracellular hydrolysis to release amino acids. These amino acids areabsorbed into the circulation from the basolateral membrane via basolateral amino acidtransporter. H+ moves out of the cell via Na+-H+ exchanger on the luminal side.Absorption of dipeptides and tripeptidesDipeptidesTripeptidesBasolateral aminoacid transportersPEPT1HNHENatCytosolicdigestionADP3Na*ATPOMARROW2K+

questions.question: Which of the following is passively absorbed in the gut?
questions.explanation: Lipids are passively absorbed in the gut.The products of lipid digestion (monoglycerides and free fatty acids) are incorporated intomicelles that are formed by bile salts and diffuse across the intestinal epithelium. Short andmedium-chain fatty acids can directly diffuse across the intestinal epithelium.Note: Recent evidence suggests that specific carrier proteins (membrane transporters) may beinvolved in the transport of long-chain fatty acids.

questions.question: Short-chain fatty acids produced by bacteria are maximally absorbed in which part of theintestine?
questions.explanation: Short-chain fatty acids produced by bacteria are absorbed maximally in the colon by secondaryactive transport.Almost all the iron absorption occurs in the duodenum.Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum.Folate is absorbed in the upper small intestine (duodenum and jejunum).Maximum water absorption takes place in the jejunum.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a function of short-chain fatty acids in the colon?

options.A: Trophic effect on the colonic epithelial cells

questions.explanation: 590Short-chain fatty acids (2-5-carbon) in the colon promote the absorption of Na+, not secretion.Short-chain fatty acids (SCFA) in the colon are formed by the action of colonic bacteria oncomplex carbohydrates, resistant starches, and other components of the dietary fiber i.e thematerial that escapes digestion in the upper gastrointestinal tract and enters the colon.Functions:• Exert a trophic effect on the colonic epithelial cells• Combat inflammation•Helps in maintaining acid-base equilibrium

questions.question: Which of the following patients is most likely to have a major electrolyte imbalance?

options.A: A patient with duodenal resection due to a primary tumor
options.B: A patient who underwent jejunal resection due to an obstruction
options.C: A patient with ileal resection due to recurrent Crohn's disease
options.D: A patient with sigmoid resection due to a recurrent fistula

questions.explanation: The resection of jejunum leads to major electrolyte imbalance because most of the fluid andelectrolyte reabsorption occurs in this segment.The maximum water absorption takes place in the jejunum.The amount of water absorbed in the intestines follows this order: Jejunum > Ileum > Colon.Almost all the iron absorption occurs in the duodenum.Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum.Folate is absorbed in the upper small intestine (duodenum and jejunum).

questions.question: What is the amount of fluid absorbed in the intestine in a day?
questions.explanation: The amount of fluid absorbed in the intestine in a day is around 8L.About 2L of ingested water and 7L of various secretions enter the gastrointestinal tract. Out ofthis, the majority (8800 mL) is absorbed in the small intestine and colon. The small remainingvolume that is not absorbed (100–200 mL) is excreted in feces.

questions.question: Which of the following is not absorbed in the colon?
questions.explanation: K+ is not absorbed in the colon. It is secreted in the rectal fluid.Electrolytes (Na+, Cl-), short-chain fatty acids (acetate, propionate, butyrate), and water areabsorbed in the colon.591Absorption in the colonBloodColonic epithelial cellNa+ōH₂OLumenNa+Na+K+K+ATPADPRROOsmosisMARROWCI-HCO3-H₂O

questions.question: Which of the following is false about vitamin absorption?

options.A: Fat-soluble vitamin digestion needs cholesterol esterase
options.B: Vitamin B12 is absorbed in ileum
options.C: Folate is absorbed by carriers that are Na+ cotransporters
options.D: Most vitamins are absorbed in upper small intestine

questions.explanation: Folate and vitamin B12 absorption is Na+-independent.The remaining water-soluble vitamins-thiamin, riboflavin, niacin, pyridoxine, pantothenate,biotin, and ascorbic acid are absorbed by carriers that are Na+ cotransporters.Option A: Fat-soluble vitamins are ingested in the form of esters. Digestion needs hydrolysis bycholesterol esterase and absorbed after incorporating into micelles.Options B and D: Most vitamins are absorbed in the upper small intestine, but vitamin B12 isabsorbed in the ileum. Vitamin B12 binds to intrinsic factor, a protein secreted by the parietalcells of the stomach. This complex is absorbed across the ileal mucosa.

questions.question: A patient with anemia is prescribed iron tablets. The absorption of the supplement is likely to take place in which part of the intestine?
questions.explanation: Almost all the iron absorption occurs in the duodenum. Most of the iron in the diet is in the ferric (Fe3+) form, whereas it is the ferrous (Fe2+) form that is absorbed. Note: Carbohydrates, proteins, lipids are absorbed throughout the length of the small intestine. Bile acids are present throughout the small intestine, but active absorption occurs only in the ileum, and active absorption of folate occurs in the upper small intestine (duodenum and jejunum).

questions.question: Which of the following stimulates ferritin synthesis?
questions.explanation: Elemental iron stimulates ferritin synthesis.592It synthesizes ferritin by causing the release of a cytoplasmic protein that binds to a specificregion in the ferritin mRNA. This disruption activates ferritin mRNA and results in its translation.Hepcidin binds to ferroportin and triggers its internalization and degradation. This results indecreased iron absorption and decreased circulating iron levels which reduces ferritin synthesis.Iron absorptionHepcidinHeme ironHemetransporterFe2+Ferroportin 1LiverDMT-1FoodFe2+Fe2+HephaestinFe3+Duodenalcytochrome BNonhemeironLost by sheddingof epithelial cells©MARROWFe3+PlasmatransferrinBloodNote: Ferritin sequesters Fe2+, a potentially toxic molecule.Erythroidmarrow

questions.question: Which of the following is inhibited by hepcidin?
questions.explanation: Hepcidin inhibits iron absorption.It is named for its originally described property as a hepatocellular protein with bactericidalactivities.Iron metabolism is regulated by hepcidin, a protein and acute phase reactant produced by theliver. It binds to ferroportin and degrades it. This inhibits the transfer of iron from the enterocyteto the plasma via ferroportin. As a result, iron becomes trapped within the duodenal cells(enterocytes) in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost in feces when these cells are shed off.593Iron absorptionHepcidinHeme ironHemetransporterFe2+Ferroportin 1LiverDMT-1Fe2+FoodFe2+Fe2+HephaestinFe3+Duodenalcytochrome BNonhemeironLost by sheddingof epithelial cellsOMARROWFe3+PlasmatransferrinBloodErythroidmarrow

questions.question: While prescribing iron to a patient with iron deficiency anemia, which of the following wouldyou recommend to increase its absorption?
questions.explanation: Ascorbic acid is given with iron to increase its absorption.Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) forms soluble complexes with iron and reduces iron from the ferric tothe ferrous state, thereby enhancing iron absorption.Option A: Milk decreases iron absorption.Option C: Gastric secretions increase iron absorption by dissolving the iron and allowing it toform soluble complexes with ascorbic and other substances. This helps in its reduction to theFe2+ form. Antacid decreases the absorption of iron.Option D: Tannins (present in tea), phytates, phosphates, and oxalates form insoluble complexeswith iron and lower its absorption.

questions.question: All of the following regulates intestinal absorption of iron except:

options.C: State of iron stores in the body
options.D: State of erythropoiesis in bone marrow

questions.explanation: Intestinal absorption of iron is not regulated by the daily loss of iron.The intestinal absorption of iron is regulated by three factors:• Recent dietary intake of iron•State of the iron stores in the body• State of erythropoiesis in the bone marrow

questions.question: What is the end product after the action of colonic bacteria on dietary fiber?
questions.explanation: 594The action of colonic bacteria on dietary fiber would give butyrate.Colonic bacteria act on complex carbohydrates, resistant starches, and dietary fiber to formshort-chain fatty acids such as acetate, propionate, and butyrate.SCFAs are 2-5-carbon weak acids that have an average normal concentration of about 80 mmol/Lin the lumen.

questions.question: Where are the cell bodies of the orexinergic neurons are present in a patient?
questions.explanation: Cell bodies of orexigenic neurons are present in the lateral hypothalamic area. Orexin stimulatesfood intake.Role of hypothalamus in gastrointestinal and feeding regulation:• Hunger center - lateral hypothalamic area• Satiety center - ventromedial nuclei•Feeding reflexes such as licking the lips and swallowing - mammillary bodies.Note: The arcuate nucleus contains at least two different types of neurons that when stimulatedlead to either increased or decreased appetite.

questions.question: In a patient who is fasting, the stomach releases a hormone that increases food intake.Identify the hormone secreted.
questions.explanation: The hormone secreted by the stomach that increases food intake is ghrelin.Ghrelin, the hunger hormone is produced by the endocrine cells in the oxyntic glands of thestomach. It increases food intake. Its levels increase during fasting, peaks just before thebeginning of food intake, or when the person is expecting a meal. The levels fall within 1 hour ofthe start of feeding.Option A: Orexin is synthesized from lateral hypothalamic neurons. It increases food intake.Option B: Leptin is produced by adipocytes. It decreases food intake.Option C: CCK is released from the small intestine. It decreases food intake.

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding ghrelin?
questions.explanation: Ghrelin increases gastric acid secretion.Ghrelin is mainly produced by the endocrine cells in the oxyntic gland area of the stomach. It isalso secreted by the pancreas and adrenal glands.Functions:• Increases appetite/food intake (orexigenic)•• Inhibits leptin release595• Stimulates growth hormone secretion by directly acting on anterior pituitary (ghrelin-growthhormone-releasing peptide)• Increases gastric acid secretion and gastrointestinal motility to prepare the body for food intake•Regulates the distribution and rate of use of energy

questions.question: What will be the trend of leptin levels in a patient with a BMI of 34 kg/m2.
questions.explanation: A patient with a BMI of 34 kg/m2 is categorized as obese. Leptin levels are high in obesity.Leptin is an appetite-suppressing hormone synthesized from adipocytes. The larger the fat stores,the more leptin is released into the blood.Leptin resistance in obese persons may be due to its failure to cross the blood-brain barrier andreach the hypothalamus to serve its appetite-suppressing function.Note: A recent study has indicated that triglycerides which are elevated in obesity, inhibit thetransport of leptin across the blood-brain barrier.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a dietary fiber?
questions.explanation: Gum is the best answer among the given options. Even though all of the given options are dietaryfibers, the consumption of gums through diet is very low and hence, it is the best answer.Dietary fibers consist of both soluble and insoluble forms and include lignin, pectin, inulin,cellulose, hemicellulose, etc.Advantages of fibers:•• Forms bulk of the stool and reduces stool transit time• Reduces incidence of carcinoma colon, DM, CAD, diverticulitis

questions.question: All of the following have a significant role in lipid digestion except:
questions.explanation: Lingual lipases are of little quantitative significance for lipid digestion other than in the setting ofpancreatic insufficiency.Lingual lipase is secreted by Ebner glands on the dorsal surface of the tongue in some species, andthe stomach also secretes lipase.Digestion of Lipids• Pancreatic lipase is the most important enzyme involved in lipid digestion. The main products ofits action are FFA and 2-monoglycerides (2-monoacylglycerols)•Colipase is an accessory factor secreted in the pancreatic juice that helps to stabilize pancreaticlipase in an active conformation596• Bile acids emulsify the insoluble lipids and make them reach the surface of the mucosal cells.Bile acids also activate another pancreatic lipase called cholesterol esterase• Cholesterol esterase hydrolyzes cholesterol esters, esters of fat-soluble vitamins, phospholipids,and triglycerides

questions.question: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have
questions.explanation: After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12deficiency.Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Vitamin B12 binds to intrinsic factor, a protein secreted bythe parietal cells of the stomach, and the complex is absorbed across the ileal mucosa. Hence afterileal resection, there is impaired absorption of vitamin B12.

questions.question: Transport molecule for Fe2+ into the enterocytes is
questions.explanation: Transport of Fe2+ into the enterocytes occurs via divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1), through anactive transport process.Protein DMT-1 (Divalent Metal Transporter-1) is expressed on the apical surface of enterocytes inthe initial part of the duodenum. DMT-1 is not specific to iron & transports other substanceslike zinc, copper, cobalt & manganese.Absorption of ironHeme ironHeme transporterHepcidinLiverFOODNonhemeiron-Ferroportin 1Duodenalcytochrome BOFe2BloodFe3+-HephaestinMucosalferritinFe2.M-DMT1Lost by sheddingof epithelial cellsOMARROWPlasmatransferrinErythroidmarrow

questions.question: Which part of the liver stores vitamin A?
questions.explanation: Vitamin A is stored in the liver perisinusoidal stellate (Ito) cells as retinyl ester (retinol palmitate).597Kupffer cells, also known as stellate macrophages and Kupffer-Borowicz cells; are specializedmacrophages located in the liver that form part of the mononuclear phagocyte system. These arepresent, lining the walls of the sinusoids, not the perisinusoidal space (Space of Disse).598
